snippet: In a case related to Dead Sea Scrolls scholars, New York judges struck down a state law banning personal communication “likely to cause annoyance or alarm.”
abstract: New York State Court of Appeals in Albany, ruling in case related to Dead Sea Scrolls, strikes down state statute that makes it a felony to communicate with someone 'in a manner likely to cause annoyance or alarm'; case involves New York City resident Raphael Golb, who waged campaign against rivals of his father, Dead Sea Scrolls scholar Norman Golb.
lead_paragraph: In a case related to Dead Sea Scrolls scholars, New York judges struck down a state law banning personal communication “likely to cause annoyance or alarm.”

headline.main: Top Court Champions Freedom to Annoy
headline.print_headline: Top Court Champions Freedom to Annoy
